title: Unilateral Progressive Mixed Hearing Loss (Otosclerosis)
chief_complaint: I have noticed some hearing loss in my right ear that has slowly gotten worse over the years, but I believe I still hear well from my left ear.

problem_summary.laterality: Right ear reported; Left ear perceived as normal.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Patient reports not being bothered by her hearing loss at this time.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Patient is currently hesitant about intervention.

history.present_illness: 70-year-old female reports slowly progressive hearing loss in the right ear with tinnitus. She perceives normal hearing in the left ear.
history.medical_psych_history: Denies family history of hearing loss.
history.patient_goals: Assessment of hearing status; currently claims not to be bothered by the loss.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear shows moderate to moderately severe mixed hearing loss in low frequencies, rising to mild mixed loss in high frequencies. Significant air-bone gaps present. Left ear shows normal to slight sensorineural hearing loss sloping to moderate in high frequencies.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT scores are in agreement with PTA bilaterally. Word recognition scores are excellent in both ears.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal tympanograms (Type A) bilaterally, despite the conductive component in the right ear.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Right ipsilateral and contralateral reflexes absent (consistent with conductive pathology). Left ipsilateral reflexes present/normal. Left contralateral reflexes absent (due to probe effect in right ear).

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with asymmetric hearing. The right ear exhibits a moderate mixed hearing loss with a significant air-bone gap, while the left ear is essentially normal sloping to a high-frequency sensorineural loss. Speech understanding is excellent bilaterally when sufficiently loud. The pattern of absent reflexes in the right ear with normal tympanograms is consistent with a middle ear pathology such as otosclerosis.
counseling_points: You have a 'mixed' hearing loss in your right ear, meaning there is a mechanical blockage preventing sound from reaching the inner ear efficiently, in addition to some natural wear-and-tear.

The specific pattern of your test results (hearing loss with normal eardrum movement but absent reflexes) strongly suggests a condition called Otosclerosis, where a tiny bone in the ear becomes stiff.
We are referring you to an ENT specialist to confirm this diagnosis.
Treatment options include surgery (to fix the stiff bone) or a hearing aid. Both would likely be very effective for you.
Since you feel you are coping well right now, it is okay to monitor the hearing, but medical clearance is still recommended.
notes_for_actor: You are calm and unbothered by your hearing loss.
You believe your 'good ear' (left) compensates enough for your daily life.
When presented with options like surgery or hearing aids, you should politely decline, stating that you feel you do well enough with your communication needs right now.
